text: was a after Shocho and before Kakitsu. This period started in September 1429 and ended in February 1441.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Eikyō" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 171. During this time, the emperor was .Nussbaum, "Go- Hanazono Tennō," p. 252; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du Japon, pp. 331-340. ==Events of the Eikyō era== * 14 April 1429 (Eikyō 1, 9th day of the 3rd month): The name of Ashikaga Yoshinobu was changed to Yoshinori.Titsingh, p. 333. * 1429: Yoshinori appointed shogun.Ackroyd, Joyce. (1982) Lessons from History: The Tokushi Yoron, p. 330. * 1433 (Eikyō 5, 6th month): Letter from Emperor of China to the Shogun assumes wrongly that the head of the Ashikaga shogunate is the "king of Japan."Titsingh, p. 335. * 1433 (Eikyō 5, 10th month): Former-Emperor Go-Komatsu died.Titsingh, p. 335; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō): 後小松天皇 (100) * 1438 (Eikyō 10): Revolt against the shogunate led by Ashikaga no Mochiuji.Nussbaum, "Eikyō no Ran" at p. 171. ==Related pages == * Muromachi period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Eikyō 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 10th 11th 12th 13th 1429 1430 1431 1432 1433 1434 1435 1436 1437 1438 1439 1440 1441 Preceded by: Shōchō Era or nengō: Eikyō Succeeded by: Kakitsu Category:Japanese eras
title: Eikyō
